Chat with an OpenAI model

Source: R/provider-openai.R
chat_openai.Rd

OpenAI provides a number of chat-based models, mostly under the ChatGPT brand. Note that a ChatGPT Plus membership does not grant access to the API. You will need to sign up for a developer account (and pay for it) at the developer platform.

For authentication, we recommend saving your API key to the OPENAI_API_KEY environment variable in your .Renviron file. You can easily edit this file by calling usethis::edit_r_environ().

Usage

chat_openai(
  system_prompt = NULL,
  turns = NULL,
  base_url = "https://api.openai.com/v1",
  api_key = openai_key(),
  model = NULL,
  seed = NULL,
  api_args = list(),
  echo = c("none", "text", "all")
)

Arguments

system_prompt

A system prompt to set the behavior of the assistant.

turns

A list of Turns to start the chat with (i.e., continuing a previous conversation). If not provided, the conversation begins from scratch.

base_url

The base URL to the endpoint; the default uses OpenAI.

api_key

The API key to use for authentication. You generally should not supply this directly, but instead set the OPENAI_API_KEY environment variable.

model

The model to use for the chat. The default, NULL, will pick a reasonable default, and tell you about. We strongly recommend explicitly choosing a model for all but the most casual use.

seed

Optional integer seed that ChatGPT uses to try and make output more reproducible.

api_args

Named list of arbitrary extra arguments appended to the body of every chat API call.

echo

One of the following options:

  • none: don't emit any output (default when running in a function).

  • text: echo text output as it streams in (default when running at the console).

  • all: echo all input and output.

Note this only affects the chat() method.

Value

A Chat object.

See also

Other chatbots: chat_bedrock(), chat_claude(), chat_cortex(), chat_databricks(), chat_gemini(), chat_github(), chat_groq(), chat_ollama(), chat_perplexity()

Examples

chat <- chat_openai()
#> Using model = "gpt-4o".
chat$chat("
  What is the difference between a tibble and a data frame?
  Answer with a bulleted list
")
#> - **Printing Behavior**:  
#>   - *Tibble*: Provides a more concise and readable print layout by 
#> default. Only the first 10 rows and as many columns as fit on the screen 
#> are shown, helping to avoid overwhelming the user with too much 
#> information.
#>   - *Data Frame*: Prints all rows and columns in the console, which can 
#> be overwhelming for large data sets.
#> 
#> - **Column Names**:  
#>   - *Tibble*: Allows for non-syntactic names (e.g., names with spaces or 
#> special characters) and retains them without modification.
#>   - *Data Frame*: Converts non-syntactic names to syntactic names 
#> automatically.
#> 
#> - **Subsetting and Recycling**:  
#>   - *Tibble*: Does not allow partial matching of column names by default 
#> and throws a clearer error if a column is missing. Does not perform 
#> automatic recycling of vectors.
#>   - *Data Frame*: Allows partial matching and might perform some 
#> recycling actions silently.
#> 
#> - **Performance**:  
#>   - *Tibble*: Often provides optimizations that can result in better 
#> performance, particularly with large data sets.
#>   - *Data Frame*: Could be slower due to older implementation methods.
#> 
#> - **Default Data Structure**:  
#>   - *Tibble*: Default data structure in the `tidyverse` suite of packages
#> in R, emphasized for improved data analysis workflow.
#>   - *Data Frame*: Base R’s standard data structure, historically used in 
#> R prior to the introduction of tibbles.
#> 
#> - **Creation**:  
#>   - *Tibble*: Can maintain a list of special column classes like time and
#> date, without changing them.
#>   - *Data Frame*: Can sometimes coerce other types to character when 
#> creating new data frames from lists or other types.
#> 
#> - **Handling of Different Data Types**:  
#>   - *Tibble*: Better at preserving special data types such as factor 
#> levels and date-times during filtering and manipulation.
#>   - *Data Frame*: May not always handle these optimally during 
#> manipulation, leading to potential conversion issues.
#> 
#> Remember that while tibbles are an enhancement of data frames intended to
#> make data manipulation easier and more intuitive, data frames are still 
#> fully compatible with tibble and provide a lot of legacy support in R 
#> programming.
